results.title: Documenting reality
results.brief_description: Documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. They have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

constellations_primary.name: Reality TV me
constellations_primary.description: Cult documentary Grey Gardens follows the everyday eccentricities of mother and daughter Big Edie and Little Edie. The women perform and speak candidly to the camera, and have been described as predecessors to reality TV stars.

results.description: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.
description_for_label: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

results.title: September 11
results.brief_description: The world held its breath as two hijacked planes were crashed into the World Trade Center in New York City on 11 September 2001. TV networks around the world bore witness and millions of people saw the historic event unfold in real time.

constellations_primary.name: Post-9/11
constellations_primary.description: The attacks on the World Trader Center in New York City on September 11 2001 were viewed on live television by audiences around the world. The effects of the attack have been explored across various forms of media.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: The world held its breath as two hijacked planes were crashed into the World Trade Center in New York City on 11 September 2001. TV networks around the world bore witness and millions of people saw the historic event unfold in real time.

results.title: Sydney Olympics
results.brief_description: ‘When Cathy Freeman carried the Aboriginal flag alongside the authorised Australian flag at the 1994 Commonwealth Games, she faced intense media scrutiny. Six years later, Australia held its breath and watched Freeman unite the country by winning gold at the 2000 Olympics.

results.title: Vietnam War
results.brief_description: The Vietnam War is known as ‘the television war’. Images from the front nightly entered people’s living rooms through on-the-ground reportage. As the war progressed, public support waned and by 1969 protests were held, which were also televised.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_other.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_other.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

results.description: The Vietnam War is known as ‘the television war’. Images from the front nightly entered people’s living rooms through on-the-ground reportage. As the war progressed, public support waned and by 1969 protests were held, which were also televised. The TV imagery from the front and protests helped turn public sentiment, and subsequent conflicts, like the Gulf War, drastically reduced media access as a result.
description_for_label: The Vietnam War is known as ‘the television war’. Images from the front nightly entered people’s living rooms through on-the-ground reportage. As the war progressed, public support waned and by 1969 protests were held, which were also televised. The TV imagery from the front and protests helped turn public sentiment, and subsequent conflicts, like the Gulf War, drastically reduced media access as a result.

results.title: Moon landing
results.brief_description: On 21 July 1969, Neil Armstrong and Edwin ‘Buzz’ Aldrin became the first people to walk on the Moon. Through a global satellite network, this historic event was broadcast around the world and united an estimated 600 million people in a single moment.

constellations_primary.name: Space, cinema and fakes
constellations_primary.description: Before and after humans stepped foot on the moon, outer-space and the stars have inspired filmmakers, artists and game makers to imagine what's beyond our atmosphere.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.description: On 21 July 1969, Neil Armstrong and Edwin ‘Buzz’ Aldrin became the first people to walk on the Moon. Through a global satellite network, including the satellite dish at the Parkes Observatory in New South Wales, this historic event was broadcast around the world and united an estimated 600 million people in a single moment.
description_for_label: On 21 July 1969, Neil Armstrong and Edwin ‘Buzz’ Aldrin became the first people to walk on the Moon. Through a global satellite network, including the satellite dish at the Parkes Observatory in New South Wales, this historic event was broadcast around the world and united an estimated 600 million people in a single moment.

results.title: Melbourne Olympics
results.brief_description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

constellations_primary.name: No guts, no glory
constellations_primary.description: TV arrived just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. The Olympics crystallise ideas of nationalism, athletic heroism, and controversy, all of which have been explored through countless features, documentaries and TV shows.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.description: After years of waiting, TV was finally broadcast in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, which was aired by all three Melbourne TV stations and was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America.

results.title: Kokoda Front Line
results.brief_description: This newsreel gave Australians the first glimpse of fighting on the Kokoda Trail and was used as propaganda. Photographer Damien Parer and director Ken G Hall restaged several combat scenes and asked viewers to join the war effort. In 1943, it won Australia’s first Oscar.

constellations_primary.name: The war effort on film
constellations_primary.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.title: Cinesound Review and Fox Movietone News
results.brief_description: From the early 20th century, newsreel films were screened in cinemas before the main feature. They showed local and global events, current affairs and advertising. Rival newsreel companies Cinesound Review and Fox Movietone News operated for several decades before TV became Australia’s main news source.

Rival newsreel companies Cinesound Review and Fox Movietone News operated for several decades before TV became Australia’s main news source.

results.title: Spectacle

constellations_primary.name: Spectacle
constellations_primary.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

constellations_primary.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_primary.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

constellations_primary.name: Hell no, we won't go
constellations_primary.description: The cultural, social, psychological and political effects of the Vietnam War have been explored through cinematic classics, musicals and comedies.

results.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. In the early 20th century, Australians received much of their information from newsreel shorts in cinemas before the main feature. This shared viewing experience represented the way film, and the media, could turn current events into spectacles, and these shorts were an important predecessor to the nightly news that followed when television arrived in the 1950s. As the century progressed, world events were broadcast directly into homes, helping accelerate social, political and cultural change. Today, technological advancements also fuel new formats, like the 24-hour news cycle and social media, which blur the lines between information and entertainment while reflecting the hope, tragedy and joy of human experience.
description_for_label: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. In the early 20th century, Australians received much of their information from newsreel shorts in cinemas before the main feature. This shared viewing experience represented the way film, and the media, could turn current events into spectacles, and these shorts were an important predecessor to the nightly news that followed when television arrived in the 1950s. As the century progressed, world events were broadcast directly into homes, helping accelerate social, political and cultural change. Today, technological advancements also fuel new formats, like the 24-hour news cycle and social media, which blur the lines between information and entertainment while reflecting the hope, tragedy and joy of human experience.
